metadata.case_name: R. K. Dalmia, R. P. Gurha, L. Chokhani and Vishnu Prasad v. State

facts.text: Bharat Insurance Company incorporated in 1896. In 1936, Dalmia purchased shares and became Director and Chairman, resigned in 1942, succeeded by brother J. Dalmia.
Head office shifted from Lahore to 10, Daryaganj, Delhi in 1947. Dalmia re-opted as Director on March 10, 1949, elected Chairman on March 19, 1949.
L. Chokhani appointed Managing Director on February 27, 1950. Dalmia appointed Principal Officer from August 20, 1954, remained Chairman and Principal Officer till September 22, 1955.
Criminal conspiracy period charged: August 1954 to September 1955. Dalmia was Chairman and Principal Officer during this period.

Company had current account in Chartered Bank of India, Australia and China Ltd. (Chartered Bank) at Bombay, safe custody account for securities there, separate current account with Punjab National Bank, Bombay. At Delhi, safe custody account with Imperial Bank of India.
Articles 116 and 117 of Memorandum and Articles of Association deal with powers of Directors.
Bye-laws passed by Directors on September 8, 1951 (Exhibit P-786), signed by K.L. Gupta, numbered by Dalmia. Genuineness disputed. Copies sent to auditor and Imperial Bank.

Bye-law 12(b): Chairman empowered to grant loans, restricted to mortgages from August 30, 1954. Clause (e): Chairman to negotiate, transfer, buy, sell Government securities, pledge, endorse, withdraw or deal with them.
On January 31, 1951, Board resolutions: open account in Chartered Bank Bombay, authorize Chokhani to operate, keep securities in safe custody there, accept instructions from Chokhani and Chordia.
Current Account No. 1120 opened at Chartered Bank Bombay on January 31, 1951. Chokhani appointed Agent at Bombay same day.
From 1951-1953, Chokhani alone operated account. From October 1, 1953, jointly with Raghunath Rai (joined 1921 as clerk, Chief Accountant 1940, Secretary-cum-Chief Accountant from August 17, 1954).
Modus operandi: Chokhani got blank cheques signed by Raghunath Rai (Delhi), signed them himself. Used two cheque books to have signed cheques ready. Raghunath Rai unaware of actual issuances.

Chokhani purchased/sold securities on behalf of company at Bombay. Most sent to Delhi (Imperial Bank), some remained at Bombay (Chartered Bank) or Reserve Bank (inscribed stock). No Board resolution empowering Chokhani; prosecution says under Dalmia's instructions, defense says general authorization in 1953.

Transactions: Purchase securities for company from broker, broker from Bhagwati Trading Company (owned by Vishnu Prasad, nephew of Chokhani, age 19 in 1954, business by Chokhani). No delivery by Bhagwati, but cheques paid to Bhagwati from company funds.
Sale transactions: Sell company securities to broker, proceeds not used to buy further securities received. Similar pattern via Bhagwati.

Funds ultimately reached Bharat Union Agencies (dealt in share speculation, owned by Dalmia directly/indirectly). Union Agencies losses Aug 1954-Sep 1955. Conspiracy to divert funds to cover losses, cover up by false entries.

Chokhani communicated contracts to head office without mentioning no securities received or cheques to Bhagwati. Raghunath Rai inquired from Dalmia, got reply purchases under instructions. Entries made, confirmed at Board meetings noting Chairman's instructions. Dalmia denies inquiries.

Auditors Khanna and Annadhanam for 1954 unsatisfied, asked for cheque counterfoils, securities. Matter surfaced via rumour to Shri Kaul (Sept 1955), led to Annadhanam appointment under s.33 Insurance Act on Sept 19, 1955.

Dalmia confessed to Annadhanam on Sept 20, 1955 (Exhibit P-10). Attempt to reimburse shortfall. Police investigation, Sessions Judge convicted appellants, High Court upheld except relying on confession.
Dalmia's defense: No involvement in details, authorized Chokhani 1953 to buy/sell securities independently, no knowledge of modus, knew Union losses, told Chokhani would arrange funds.
Chokhani admits transactions to meet Union losses, expected repayment, thought it was loan, would have used other means if known wrongful.
Vishnu Prasad ignorant of transactions, acted on Chokhani instructions.
Gurha denies fabrication of accounts in conspiracy.
Union Agencies losses: Brokers demand Rs.22,25,687-13-0 on Aug 6, 1954. Cash assets Rs.2,67,857-11-7. Telephonic communications Dalmia-Chokhani Aug 7-14, 1954.
Aug 7 & 9, 1954: Rs.2L & 3L to Punjab National Bank Bombay for Union Agencies from Delhi.
Vishnu Prasad opened Bhagwati accounts: Bank of India Aug 9 Rs.1100, United Bank Aug 11 Rs.1100, supplied by Chokhani. No actual business.
Example transaction Aug 9, 1954: Chokhani buys Rs.22L 3%1963-65 securities for Insurance from Naraindas & Sons, cross-sells same for Bhagwati to same broker. No delivery, payment to Bhagwati.
Similar Aug 11, 1954: Rs.5L securities.

legal_issues.text: Whether Delhi Court had territorial jurisdiction to try offences of criminal breach of trust committed by Chokhani at Bombay under s.120B/409 IPC.
Whether misjoinder of charges fatal and not curable under ss.531/537 CrPC.
Whether substantive charge under s.409 IPC against Dalmia offends s.233 CrPC.
Whether funds in bank account constitute 'property' under ss.405/409 IPC and whether Dalmia had dominion over them.
Whether Dalmia/Chokhani are 'agent' within s.409 IPC (professional agency required?).
Admissibility of Dalmia's confessional statement (s.24 Evidence Act, Art.20(3) Constitution).
Whether prosecution proved Dalmia synonymous with Bharat Union Agencies.
Onus of proof and approach to evidence of Raghunath Rai (accomplice needing corroboration).
Whether Dalmia had knowledge of impugned transactions at the time.

petitioner_arguments.text: Delhi Court no jurisdiction over Bombay offences; misjoinder fatal, not curable s.531/537 CrPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC ss.233, 531, 537; Purushottam Das Dalmia v. State of WB (reconsideration sought)

petitioner_arguments.text: Bank funds not 'property' under s.405/409 IPC (chose in action, not movable); Dalmia no dominion (no specimen signature to bank).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: IPC s.405; Attorney General for Canada v. AG Quebec; Reg v. Girdhar Dharamdas; Jugdown Sinha v. Queen Empress

petitioner_arguments.text: Dalmia/Chokhani not 'agent' under s.409 (requires professional agency business).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: IPC s.409; Reg v. Portugal; Mahumarakalage Edward Andrew Cooray v. The Queen

petitioner_arguments.text: Confession inadmissible (s.24 Evidence Act, Art.20(3) Constitution).
No proof Dalmia = Union Agencies; courts failed onus/approach to Raghunath Rai (accomplice); no knowledge of transactions.

respondent_arguments.text: Jurisdiction ok as overt acts in pursuance of conspiracy triable where conspiracy tried.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Purushottam Das Dalmia v. State of WB

respondent_arguments.text: 'Property' wide, includes bank funds (chose in action); dominion exists via company powers.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: IPC ss.22,405; DCG Mills v. Harnam Singh

respondent_arguments.text: 'Agent' includes directors/chairman/agent in course of business/duties.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: IPC s.409; Palmers Company Law; Peoples Bank v. Harkishen Lal

court_reasoning.text: Delhi Court has jurisdiction over s.409 offences in pursuance of conspiracy (follows Purushottam Das Dalmia). No misjoinder/vagueness prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court with conspiracy jurisdiction tries overt acts beyond jurisdiction if in pursuance.

court_reasoning.text: Bank funds are 'property' under s.405 (wide meaning, includes chose in action/debt).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No restriction to movables; dominion via power to operate, even if not exercised.

court_reasoning.text: Dalmia/Chokhani have dominion: Chairman/Principal Officer/Agent powers under Articles/Bye-laws/Resolutions to operate accounts/deal securities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bye-laws P-786/897 proved genuine despite disputes.

court_reasoning.text: 'Agent' in s.409 includes those entrusted in way of business as agent (course of duties), not just professionals. Directors/agents qualify.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entrustment in capacity and course of duties as agent.

court_reasoning.text: Chokhani had dominion jointly, but blank cheques gave sole control. Not cheating as dominion from Board resolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Joint dominion sufficient; facilitation not negate entrustment.

holdings.text: Delhi Court has jurisdiction over conspiracy overt acts.
Bank funds are 'property' under s.405 IPC.
Dalmia/Chokhani had dominion over funds as Chairman/Agent.
Dalmia/Chokhani 'agents' under s.409 IPC in course of business/duties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Purushottam Das Dalmia v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction over overt acts in pursuance of conspiracy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Attorney General for Canada v. Attorney General for Province of Quebec
Ram Chand Gurwala v. King Emperor
The Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. v. Harnam Singh
Mahumarakalage Edward Andrew Cooray v. The Queen
precedents_cited.relevance: Agent in penal code equivalent to s.409.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Conspiracy with CBT by agent/public servant; definition of property/CBT.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected procedural objections, held bank funds as property, Dalmia/Chokhani as agents with dominion, upheld lower courts' findings on jurisdiction and entrustment substantially.

key_quotes.text: "The word 'property' is used in the Code in a much wider sense than the expression 'movable property'."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets scope of 'property' in IPC s.405.

key_quotes.text: "Directors are not only agents but they are in some sense and to some extent trustees or in the position of trustees."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The expression 'in the way of his business' means... in the ordinary course of his duty or habitual occupation or profession or trade."
key_quotes.speaker: court
